p.s: In the following text I will analyse the given scene regarding cinematic devices and the way George Tillmann Jr. presents Chris and Starr.
The most important message of the scene is that Chris really cares about Starr as his girlfriend, but also Starr's way of showing him that she isn't ok with what Chris has done before (condom-gate).
The scene can be devideddivided in three parts.
The first part Chris going through the school hall shaking hands with his friends.
The second part him dancing on the school hall to his own remix.
As just said before in the first part of the scene the audience sees Chris coming to school and going to Starr.
He is shown in several medium shots or medium close ups to clearly state him as the most important character of this sequence.
Furthermore we get to see his good mood like this in a very good way.
He seems like someone who is always smiling and always tries to see the good thing in everything.
Besides the number of close shots in which Chris is shown to the beginning there are also other cinematic devices making him seem more popular.
One of them is the slow motion.
George Tillmann Jr. used this slow motion to make Starr seem cooler and more popular to the audience.
Because of the therefore longer shown handshakings and greetings with his friends we think that he is a guy everybody likes at school and who everybody wants to be a friend with.

That this isn't true in whole and that Chris does not fit in this stereotypstereotype of the popular white guy at an americanAmerican high school the audience experiences in the second part of the scene which begins after the song Ocean Eyes stopped, which made the first part seem like a foreshadow for the audience saying him This is Starr's boyfriend, look at him, he is cool but also a good partner for a relationship.

About the last point I want to talk more specifically because in the secondesecond part of the scene the audience gets to know much about Starr's and Chris' relationship and Chris' attitude to their situation.
At the beginning of the secondesecond part we see Starr through a close up from the angle out of her locker.
Chris appears behind her putting his earphones on Starr's head.
Starr now hears a self made remix from Chris which she normally likes very much.
The audience gets to know this through a voice over in which Starr tells us exactly this.
But on this day Starr doesn't want to hear Chris' music, because she wants to talk with him seriously.

But that Starr feels still happy having Chris as her friend the audience gets to know, otherwise than Chris, through the voice over, but also because of the close ups showing her facial expressions fighting between a serious look and a smile.

Like this the scene is forshadowedforeshadowed for the audience because he/she now knows, that Starr will try to act seriously at the beginning of their conversation, but to the end will agree to Chris making clear that she doesn't want to have a case like condom-gate again.
About like this their conversation which is shown through many over-the-shoulder and reverse-shots, happens.
Both characters are shown in several close ups showing their facial expressions, which in both cases show their seriousness.
Furthermore all shots are taken an eyelevel which should clearly state that the both youths in general want to come to a good solution for both sides.
This solution is also hitted in the conversation in which Chris clearly shows that he can be a good boyfriend for Starr caring about her and being theirthere for her.
Like this the audience gets to see ChrisChris' character as a boyfriend which can be clearly stated as aan antagonist to his stereotypstereotype as the popularepopular guy.
In the third part of the scene Chris turns on his music loud starting to dance to it.
He is shown in a medium long shot which makes it easy to see his joyness while he is dancing.
Furthermore he is again shown in a slow motion which again clearly states his coolness but also what Starr likes so much at him, he always gets her laughing.
Starr's feelings at this moment are again shown through a voice over.
To have a conclusion in this scene Chris is presented as the cool seeming guy who everybody likes at school.
He acts like a perfect stereotyped guy for this role, but when he comes to Starr he becomes serious.
He acts like a good boyfriend for Starr who wants to achieve a good relationship for both sides.
At the end he tries to convince Starr by doing what he knows she loves at him (making her laugh).
